docs.abstract: Recent Journal of Women's Health paper lends credence to theory that hormone replacement therapy can be beneficial if started around onset of menopause, but is potentially harmful if started at later time; Dr JoAnn Manson, Brigham and Women's Hospital preventive medicine chief and lead author of study, says determining hormone usage is complex issue with many options; in past, doctors often prescribed hormone replacement therapy for women solely to help prevent heart disease; use of therapy is currently reserved for women who experience difficult symptoms of menopause; studies on hormone replacement therapy described; photo; drawing (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Candace Talmadge was determined to get through menopause without using hormones, and she tried just about every alternative treatment she could find, like soy tablets, herbs and acupuncture, a chiropractor and even an anti-anxiety medication. Two months ago, Ms. Talmadge's doctor suggested that she consider hormone therapy, and she relented.

headline.main: Children, Media and Sex: A Big Book of Blank Pages

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses how media-rich environment shapes children's views about sex; research suggests that children who view more television with sexual content behave as though they are 9 to 17 months older than they actually are; photo; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In last summer's prize-winning R-rated film ''Me and You and Everyone We Know,'' a barely pubescent boy is seduced into oral sex by two girls perhaps a year older, and his 6-year-old brother logs on to a pornographic chat room and solicits a grown woman with instant messages about ''poop.'' Is this what your teenage children are watching? If so, what message are they getting about sexual mores, and what effect will it have on their behavior?
docs.snippet: What message are children getting about sexual mores, and what effect will it have on their behavior?
